metadata.description: John Denver was one of America’s greatest country-folk singer-songwriters. With over 30 albums, he was more than a performer—he was an actor, environmentalist, and humanitarian. His music captured everyday life with deep conviction, especially in 'Take Me Home, Country Roads,' now one of West Virginia’s four state anthems. Bio: Robert Santelli was named Executive Director of the GRAMMY Museum in Los Angeles in 2006. Under his leadership, the Museum opened new locations, curated over 65 exhibits, produced 600+ public programs, and partnered with the White House and The Kennedy Center for education. A noted blues and rock historian, Santelli has contributed to Rolling Stone and The New York Times and authored over a dozen books, including the New York Times bestsellers Greetings From E Street and The Bob Dylan Scrapbook. He was an original curator of the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and its first Director of Education and VP of Public Programs. In 2000, he became CEO of Seattle’s Experience Music Project (now MoPOP), the first interactive music museum. He also developed the UK’s first pop music museum, the British Music Experience. In 2012, Santelli co-produced Woody at 100: The Woody Guthrie Centennial Collection, earning a GRAMMY® nomination. After the GRAMMY Museum merged with the GRAMMY Foundation in 2017, he was named Founding Executive Director and now oversees its traveling exhibits and external projects.
